title: 115_s1047
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" designates the Lumbee Indians and amends the Act of June 7, 1956 by removing section 2 and making changes to the first section. The Lumbee Recognition Act makes amendments to the Act of June 7, 1956 by reorganizing and revising certain sections, including defining key terms in section 2. The Lumbee Recognition Act defines key terms such as Secretary and Tribe, and includes a section on Federal Recognition. The Lumbee Recognition Act extends federal recognition to the Tribe as petitioner number 65. All US laws applicable to Indians and Indian tribes also apply to the Tribe and its members. Any group of Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties, North Carolina, not enrolled in the Tribe may petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. Eligibility for federal services is outlined in the Act. The Lumbee Recognition Act grants federal recognition to the Tribe, making them eligible for all services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific North Carolina counties are considered to be on or near an Indian reservation for service delivery purposes. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, determines the needs of eligible members after verifying the tribal roll. The Lumbee Recognition Act grants federal recognition to the Tribe, making them eligible for services and benefits. The tribal roll defines the service population, subject to verification by the Secretary within 2 years of enactment. The Lumbee Recognition Act grants federal recognition to the Tribe, allowing the Secretary to take land into trust for the Tribe's benefit, including land in Robeson County, North Carolina. This land can be used for gaming activities as defined by the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act. The State of North Carolina retains jurisdiction. The Lumbee Recognition Act grants federal recognition to the Tribe, allowing the Secretary to take land into trust for the Tribe's benefit in North Carolina. The State of North Carolina shall exercise jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on the Tribe's land. The Secretary may accept jurisdiction transfers from the State to the United States based on agreements between the Tribe and the State. The Lumbee Recognition Act grants federal recognition to the Tribe, allowing the Secretary to take land into trust for the Tribe's benefit in North Carolina. The State of North Carolina shall exercise jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on the Tribe's land. A transfer of jurisdiction described in paragraph (1) may not take effect until 2 years after the effective date of the agreement. Nothing in this section affects the application of section 109 of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the Lumbee Recognition Act.
